loans.use: To paint the walls of his shop and renovate it and to increase sales.

loans.name: Jose Manuel

texts.es: José tiene 23 años de edad y es soltero. Vive en casa de sus padres en el distrito de Olmos, una zona agrícola de bastante movimiento comercial que se encuentra situada en la provincia de Lambayeque, a más de una hora y media de la ciudad de Chiclayo. José gana la vida brindando el servicio de transporte de pasajeros en su mototaxi, un vehículo que consta de una moto y una cabina para movilizar personas en su interior. Tiene dos años de experiencia en el rubro y cuenta con muy buenas referencias personales y laborales. Conoce a la perfección esta actividad porque la aprendió de su padre, quien lo apoya en sus deberes diaria del negocio. Desea usar el préstamo para el mantenimiento y reparación de su mototaxi. Necesita mantener su vehículo en buenas condiciones para seguir ofreciendo un buen servicio a sus clientes. Por ello, ha creído conveniente solicitar un préstamo de 1000 nuevos soles a Edpyme Alternativa (Kiva Field Partner).
texts.en: Jose is 23 years old and he is single. He lives in his parents' house in the district of Olmos, an agricultural region with significant commercial movement located in the province of Lambayeque. It is located more than an hour and a half from the city of Chiclayo. Jose earns a living by providing passenger transportation services on his motorcycle rickshaw. It is a vehicle consisting of a motorcycle and a cabin where to to transport passengers. He has two years’ experience in the field and he has very good personal and work-related references. He knows this business very well having learned it from his father. He supports him with his daily business obligations. He wants to use his loan to carry out maintenance and repairs to his motorcycle rickshaw. He needs to maintain his vehicle in good condition to be able to keep offering his clients a good level of service. For this reason he has approached Edpyme Alternativa (Kiva Field Partner) for a loan in the amount of 1000 nuevos soles.

loans.use: to carry out maintenance and repairs for his rickshaw

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael P. is from the village of Pandan, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. He is 26 years old and single. To make a living, he owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling educational and learning booklets in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately $250 a month for these activities.

In 2011, Michael joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional stocks of booklets and books. This will be his 1st loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more booklets and books to sell

loans.name: Arlyn

texts.en:
Arlyn M. is from the village of Catibac, Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 26 years old. Arlyn is married and has six adult-aged children. 

To make a living, Arlyn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, snack foods, detergents, shampoo, soap and biscuits in the local community . Arlyn has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2011, Arlyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Arlyn is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods and snack foods. This will be the first loan taken out by Arlyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods and snack  foods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more trees for timber and to buy a motorcycle to start another business

loans.name: Simplicia

texts.en:
Simplicia V. is from the village of Cabisera 17-21, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 60 years old. Simplicia is married and has three adult children. 

To make a living, Simplicia makes and sells general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Simplicia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Simplicia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Simplicia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. 

Simplicia is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 23 years old and single. He lives with two family members; only one of them works. 

Hussein has been the owner of a barber shop since 2008. He has four years' experience; he is specialized in haircuts for men and children. He has an excellent reputation and he is well known in his area.


 He is requesting a $2400 loan to buy new shaving machines and a massage machine and to renovate his shop. He aspires for a better future through good financial returns.

loans.use: To buy new shaving machines and a massage machine.

loans.name: Cecile

texts.en:
Cecile O. is from the village of Bonbon, Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 45 years old. Cecile is widowed. 

To make a living, Cecile owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, snack foods, beverages, shampoo, soap and breads. Cecile has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2011, Cecile joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Cecile is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods and snack foods. This will be the first loan taken out by Cecile from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods and snack foods

loans.name: Oyuntsetseg

texts.en:
Oyuntsetseg S. is a 38-year-old woman who lives with her husband and five children in a ger, a Mongolian traditional nomadic housing tent, in Uvs province, Mongolia. 

Her four sons go to a local secondary school while the only daughter stays home. 

Her husband is a herder. 

Oyuntsetseg owns a grocery trading business in her town. She sells many kinds of grocery items such as vegetables, drinks, candies and some dairy products as well. She has been managing her business for 10 years and has gained much experience. Now her monthly net profit is 150,000 to 200,000 MNT. 

As a result of her successful business operation she had been able to buy a car and some livestock for her husband. 

She is a polite woman who says, "I want to have my own house in the future." 

She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT  loan to purchase garlic, potatoes and some other grocery items for her business.

loans.use: to purchase garlic, potatoes and other grocery items

loans.name: Faridun

texts.ru: Салимов Фаридун проживает в районе Восеъ. Ему 28 лет. Он женат, имеет двоих детей. Живет вместе с родителями. Его отец пенсионер, а брат работает в дехканском хозяйстве. Сам Фаридун занимается растениеводством. Он арендует участок земли, где выращивает овощи. Этим видом деятельности занимается 7 лет. Целью кредита является закуп семян и минеральных удобрений для посева капусты.
texts.en: Faridun S. lives in the region of Vose. He is 28 years old. He is married and has two children. They live together with parents. His father is retired and his brother works in the collective farm. Faridun does agriculture, he rents out a plot of land where he grows vegetables. He has been in this business for seven years. The purpose of this loan is to buy seeds and mineral fertilizer for sowing of cabbage.

loans.use: to buy seeds and mineral fertilizer for sowing of cabbage

loans.name: Teonita

texts.en:
Teonita A. is from the village of Bonbon, Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 46 years old. Teonita is married and has six school-aged children. 

To make a living, Teonita makes and sells snacks and other delicacies like suman (a type of rice cake)  in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In the picture is Teonita and her daughter, who helps her in making snacks.

In 2011, Teonita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teonita is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed like coconuts, milk and sugar. This will be the first loan taken out by Teonita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients like coconuts, milk and sugar

loans.name: Ildephonse

texts.en: Ildephonse, age 30 and married, owns and operates a motorcycle transport business that is open daily from 6 a.m. until 10 p.m. His business is well-organized. Ildephonse has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to buy a new motorcycle. With this profit, he plans to reinvest in his business and to save for his future.

loans.use: to buy a new motorcycle for his transport business

loans.name: Tsagaanbandi

texts.en:
Tsagaanbandi T., 41, lives with his wife and two sons in a ger, a Mongolian traditional nomadic housing tent in Zavhan province, Mongolia. 

His older son goes to a local secondary school while his younger son stays home with his mother. 

He operates a taxi service business in his town. He started his business in 2008. Since then he has been able to stabilize his business and is planning to continue it in the future. 

Unfortunately his younger son is ill and requires frequent treatment. Therefore he spends all of his earnings for his son's treatment. 

He is a diligent man who says, "I am very thankful to your bank for giving me the loan for my son's treatment." 

He is requesting a 650,000 MNT of loan to pay his son's treatment expense.

loans.use: to pay his son's medical treatment

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase clothes for sale and for further tailoring

loans.name: Taj's Group

texts.en:
Taj lives in Jaranwala which is a small city in Punjab, Pakistan, known for its agriculture industry. She lives there in the area of Rasheed Park with her family. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her son who runs a small restaurant in the community. In the restaurant, he sells Punjabi food items such as "Nan chanay" (made with chick peas and served with bread) and "Biryani" (made with rice and chicken served with pickles) to his customers. He is well-known among his customers for his good quality and taste.  Using the loan, he will purchase chick peas, rice, cooking oil and spices, etc. to make good quality food to sell to his customers at a profit. 
 
Taj and her husband G. S. both are very supportive persons. They both support their son in his business. S. supports him by handling his customers in the restaurant and Taj helps him by making food for his restaurant.  

Taj is confident that the loan investment will bring better profits to her son’s business and he will be able to increase his clientele. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Taj.

loans.use: To buy required items such as chick peas, rice, cooking oil and spices for restaurant.

loans.name: Sumber Usaha Group

texts.en:
Sumber Usaha group is located in Sari Mekar, Pemuteran Village, Singaraja. This group has a total membership of 10 people, and all members of the group are women who are married and have children. This group has loans of  Rp. 10,000,000, and the person who is responsible for the group is Ni Wayan I. S.. Ni Wayan I. S. is Sumber Usaha's leader. 

Ni Wayan I. S. has good experience in managing the business of pigs, but because her capital is only slight, her business did not develop and produces a small profit. Therefore Ni Wayan I. S. chose to borrow capital at MUK. Ni Wayan I. S. gets a loan of Rp. 1,000,000 to be used to buy superior piglets and also to buy their feed. With this loan, she hopes this effort will go forward and succeed so as to improve the economy of her family.

loans.use: To buy superior piglets.

loans.name: Jinane

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. She is 25 years old and married. She has three children and her husband is a worker. 

Jinane has had her own beauty center for women since 2009; she has four years' experience in this field. She has an excellent reputation and she is well known in her local area.

She is requesting a $2000 loan to buy a new machine for massage and a machine for cleaning faces. She aspires for a better future through good financial returns.

loans.use: To buy a new machine for massage and a machine for cleaning faces.

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina B. is from the village of Bonbon, Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 44 years old. Josefina is married and has four school-aged children. 

To make a living, Josefina buys and sells green bananas in the local community. Josefina has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Josefina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Josefina is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional green bananas. This will be the first loan taken out by Josefina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional green bananas

loans.name: Bonne Nouvelle Group

texts.fr: Barhabuligwarhiro N.  est entrepreneur, présidente du groupe d’affaire « Bonne Nouvelle »,  âgée de 47 ans, mariée, mère de 8 enfants et tous fréquentent l’école. Son mari est instructeur, directeur d’une école primaire. Elle fait le petit commerce des articles divers. Elle a une boutique légèrement équipée dans sa parcelle. Elle  commença son business  avec son fonds propre reçu de son mari. Il ya 10 ans, qu’elle est en activité. Elle vient de réaliser 6 cycles opérationnels en bénéficiant de crédit de l’IMF  Hekima. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner avec des nouveaux articles (1 bidon d’huile  de table raffinée  Rina, 1 carton de biscuits, 25 kilo de sucre, dizaine de lotion de beauté, etc. En plus, elle ambitionne agrandir son entreprise et diversifier les produits.  La cliente Barhabuligwarhiro N. remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique. Il sied de signaler que le groupe d’affaire « Bonne Nouvelle » est majoritairement féminins.
texts.en: Barhabuligwarhiro N., an entrepreneur and the president of the business group "Bonne Nouvelle," is 47 years old, married and the mother of 8 children, who all go to school.  Her husband is a teacher and the principal of a primary school.  She runs a small business selling various items.  She has a lightly-equipped boutique on her plot of land.  She began her business with her own funds, received from her husband.  She has been in business for 10 years.  She has had 6 operational cycles receiving loans from the IMF Hekima.  This new loan will allow her to stock up on new items (a drum of Rina refined table oil, a box of cookies, 25 kilograms of sugar, a dozen beauty lotions, etc).  Moreover, she hopes to grow her business and diversify the products.  The client Barhabuligwarhiro N. thanks Hekima for its investments in favor of the poor excluded from classic banks.  It is suitable to point out that the business group "Bonne Nouvelle" is mostly women.

loans.use: to purchase a drum of Rina refined table oil, a box of cookies, 25 kilograms of sugar, a dozen beauty lotions, etc.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Batmunkh

texts.en:
Batmunkh B. is 28 years old and lives with his wife and 6-year-old son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live in a one-bedroom studio apartment that he bought with savings from when he and his family used to work in Korea. 

Batmunkh has operated a taxi service in the city since 2008 and has gained a lot of experience. He enjoys transporting people and is a trusted driver for his many customers. 

Batmunkh is a humble and optimistic person. He is planning to buy a two-bedroom apartment in the future. Therefore he is requesting a loan to buy some spare parts for his car.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for his taxi

loans.name: Arman

texts.en:
Arman M. was born in 1986. He lives in Sevkar village, in the Ijevan area, with his wife, his parents, and a brother.

After serving in the Armenian army, Arman joined his family's business. Specifically, he and his family are engaged in cattle-breeding, beekeeping, and farming. Arman says that farming is a very hard business, not only because it is labor-intensive, but also because he has to defend the beehives from bears, who sometimes steal them from the villagers. Since last month Arman has also worked as a truck driver to supplement his income while he continues with his farming operations.

This would be Arman’s second loan from both Kiva and Nor Horizon. He is seeking a loan in the amount of 600,000 AMD ($1,600) to buy some calves for his farm and to increase the number of his beehives.

loans.use: To buy calves for his farm and to expand his beekeeping operations

loans.name: Loni

texts.en:
Loni B. is a 30-year-old, married woman from the village of Balbagon, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She and her husband have two school-age children. To earn a living, Loni owns and operates a business venture in the food sector. Specifically, she operates a small restaurant. Her primary source of income is derived from serving a variety of different traditional Filipino meals (such as afritada, caldereta, and bulalo) to customers in her local community. Loni has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2009, Loni joined HSPFI to gain much-needed access to financial services. As a result, she is better able to engage in business activities and to thereby improve her family's standard of living. Recently, Loni successfully repaid a previous loan in the amount of 13,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase food and drinks for the restaurant. Loni is now requesting another loan, this time in the amount of 14,000 PHP ($325), which will be used to purchase additional ingredients like vegetables, spices, and meats. Notably, this loan would be the fifth loan taken out by Loni from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business as a result of the loan to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City, and its aim is to reach out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase additional food ingredients (e.g., vegetables, spices, and meats)

loans.name: Magdaline

texts.en:
Magdalene M. P. is a 38-year-old, married woman. She and her husband, P., have three children. For ten years, she has been running a retail shop, but she also farms as a secondary business. She earns a monthly income of approximately 15,000 KES.

She learned about KADET LTD through a credit officer, and she is applying for her first loan in the amount of 30,000 KES ($375) from KADET LTD. With the requested loan proceeds, she would like to buy an additional stock of flour, sugar, and cooking fat. She explains that she intends to use the anticipated profits generated as a result of the loan to save for her family's future needs and to pay her children's school fees. In the future, she would like to grow her business and to become financially stable.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory (e.g., flour, sugar, and cooking fat)

loans.name: Sesihle Group

texts.en:
Irene (pictured with her hand raised) is a 39-year-old, married woman. She and her husband have six children, who are between the ages of 8 and 21 years old. Four of their children currently attend school.

Her husband is self-employed, while she runs a clothing business in Kwa Zulu Natal of Empangeni in South Africa. She explains that she has been in this business for 1.5 years, and that her main business challenge is dealing with customers who do not want to pay on time if they had purchased clothing on credit.

She requested this loan through Women’s Development Businesses (WDB) and Kiva to buy clothes for re-sale purposes. She says that the extra income she expects will be generated as a result of this loan will be used to help send her children to school. In the future she would like to own her own shop in the mall where she would continue to sell her goods. With the help of this loan through WDB and Kiva, she can see a promising future for her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional clothes for re-sale purposes

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 29-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives with one parent. He has owned a carpentry shop since 2000. He works upon clients' requests and he also collaborates with some galleries. He produces a variety of unique wood designs which is the best method of attracting customers.  His business income is very important because he is responsible for paying the household expenses. 

 He has taken advantage of a first Kiva loan and was an excellent client with punctual payments. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1300 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional wood products. He is working on new designs and needs these purchases to complete the work. In the future, he is planning to expand his business operation by taking on bigger projects and working with construction entrepreneurs to improve his business and earn more income.

loans.use: to purchase additional wood products.

loans.name: Salamti's Group

texts.en:
Salamti belongs to Khanewal which is a small city in Punjab, Pakistan, known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there with her family in a 2-room brick house in the area of Shanti Nagar for the past 10 years. She is a housewife and spends most of her time at home doing her household work. She is a mother of one daughter who is 6 years old and has yet not started getting an education due to financial constraints. 

She is married to S. who is a farmer by trade and involved in agriculture. He grows different seasonal crops and sells them to his clients after harvesting, for a profit. 

Salamti has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy fertilizers, seeds and pesticides, etc. to grow crops and earn better profits. 

He has been operating this business for the past eight years and Salamti is hopeful that an investment will help him getting maximum profits from his hard work. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Salamti.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, seeds and pesticides for agriculture business.

loans.name: Estrelita

texts.en:
Estrelita D. is a 57-year-old woman from the village of Bonfal West, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. Estrelita is separated from her spouse and has four adult-age children. To earn a living, Estrelita owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector. Specifically, she runs a general store, where her primary source of income is derived from selling both food and everyday products to members of her local community. Estrelita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2010, Estrelita joined ASKI to gain much-needed access to financial services. As a result, she was better able to engage in business activities and to thereby improve her standard of living. Recently, Estrelita successfully repaid a previous loan in the amount of 10,000 PHP ($250) from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Estrelita is now requesting another loan, again in the amount of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Notably, this loan would be the third loan taken out by Estrelita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business as a result of the loan to financially support her immediate family members. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen/women, and entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase additional items and to expand her product offering

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet is a 32-year-old married woman with four children living in a rented house in Fort Portal, Uganda. She takes care of the family with the help of her husband, who is a businessman. Their dream is to build a residential house.

Annet sells clothes. She has been in this business for four years and the business is promising as she started with six million UGX and now she has a working capital of eight million UGX. She has a challenge in the seasonal nature of the business. Her aspiration is to own at least four outlets.

Annet needs the loan to buy clothes for resale.

loans.use: To buy clothes to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase up-to-date materials and supplies.

loans.name: Amy

texts.en:
Amy is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a pottery business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 17,000 through NWTF to buy additional materials for pottery and for renovation of her pottery business.  Amy has been in this business for 8 years. She earns other income from fishing.

Amy is sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF.   She hopes to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional materials for pottery business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia lives in Khanewal which is a small city located in Punjab province, Pakistan, and known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there in the area of Shanti Nagar for the past 15 years in a 2-room brick house with her family. 

She is married to S. Q. who is engaged in an animal-selling business. His business grows busier during the Muslim festival of Eid-ul-Azha because people purchase animals to slaughter. At other times he sells animals to butchers. He purchases young goats and sheep at cheap prices and sells them after raising them.
 
Razia herself is a seamstress, involved in a business sewing clothes. She does this work for her neighboring clients to earn income for the family. She is very skillful in her work and receives regular orders every month. She has given birth to a son and a daughter. Both are very young and have not started to attend school yet. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her husband’s business. With the loan, he will purchase some goats and sheep to earn more profit through selling. He has been operating this business for the past eight years and Razia is hopeful that an investment will put his business in a more profitable position. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Razia.

loans.use: To buy goats & sheep for animal selling business.

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en:
Thomas M. M. has been a shopkeeper for two years and earns an income of KES 10,000 in a month. The business location is in Tala town. He is married and the father of two children.

He was introduced to KADET Ltd. by a credit officer and he is applying for a loan of KES 30,000 from KADET, with which he plans to add more stock of sugar, cooking oil and cosmetics for sale.

With the anticipated profit, he will invest in the business for it to grow and also pay school fees for his child.

loans.use: to buy more stock of sugar, cooking oil and cosmetics for sale

loans.name: Elishbah's Group

texts.en:
Elishbah is 35 years old and married to N. M., who operates a scrap business. He sells scrap to different factories and other scrap dealers on order. 

Elishbah is very supportive lady and does her household responsibilities as a housewife very well.  She lives in a small city called Khanewal in a 2-room brick house with her family. Khanewal is located in Punjab province of Pakistan and known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there for over 10 years.  

She is the mother of five children. Her eldest son is a motor mechanic, while others are studying in different classes. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the betterment of her husband’s scrap business. Using the loan, he will buy scrap such as plastic bottles, used paper, etc. in bulk quantity to fulfill orders on time and to earn good profits. He has been doing this business for the past 10 years and Elishbah is confident that a loan will be productive for him. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. In the previous loan year, she established a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Elishbah.

loans.use: To buy scrap for scrap business.

loans.name: Joseph Kilonzo

texts.en:
Joseph Kilonzo K. is 39 years old and married. He has been operating a restaurant business for two years in Tala town, and he earns a monthly profit of KES 10,000.

He was introduced to KADET Ltd. by a group member and he is applying for a second loan from KADET, with which he plans to buy more cereals and meat for the restaurant.

He will invest the anticipated profits into the business for it to grow and be stable financially.

loans.use: to buy cereals and meat for the restaurant

loans.name: Shaffic

texts.en:
Shaffic is a 25-year-old hardworking man living in Fort Portal, Uganda.The responsibility to look after two of his children solely rests on him, and his dream is to educate them to attain a degree as a minmum qualification.He has been in the entertainment service business for five years after being forced to withdraw from school due to insufficient funds to pay school fees.

Shaffic has a mobile disco and an electronics shop, both very profitable despite challenges posed by the high taxes levied on him by the council authorities. His dream is to own a big cinema hall and improve the quality of his machines. Shaffic needs the loan to buy a radio and speakers.

loans.use: to buy a radio and speakers.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna S., from the village of Cabisera 17-21, Ilagan, Isabela, is 30 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Lorna has been raising pigs for fattening and sale for over 12 years, earning approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Lorna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 18,000 PHP that was used to purchase breeding livestock, she is now requesting her fifth loan for 18000 PHP to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Lorna plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Munira

texts.en:
K. Munira, a 43-year-old married mother of two children, lives with her family in the village of Bakhmal. Engaged in the selling of foods and industrial products for four years, Munira is hoping to receive a loan of 5000 Somoni to maintain and expand her business. This loan will enable her to increase her sales and to earn more money.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes its role as a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. loans.name: Margret

texts.en: Margret is a 25-year-old, single mother of two children living in her parents' house in Fort Portal, Uganda. She is charged with the responsibility of taking care of of the family with the help of her mother. Her dream is to buy land and construct a commercial house. For 3 years she has been selling clothes. The business is growing steadily despite challenges in irregular sells due to the seasonal nature of the business. Margret needs the loan to buy clothes to sell. Her dream is to own a boutique one day.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Tserenbaljir

texts.en:
Tserenbaljir is a 42-year-old women who lives with her husband and three children in a house in Zavhan province, Mongolia. Her older daughter, 22, goes to a college and her younger two daughters, 12 and 14, attend local secondary school. Her husband operates a carpentry business. 

Tserenbaljir manages a grocery trading business. She started her business in 1987. She plants and harvests her vegetables and sells them at her grocery store. She is a hardworking women who says, "I am a regular customer of XacBank and am happy to cooperate with you." She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase potatoes and to pay the tuition fee of her older daughter.

loans.use: to pay her daughter's tuition and also to purchase potatoes

To make a living, Dolorita owns and operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing wood-planing services to local community members. Dolorita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 7,500 PHP a month for these activities. Her husband operates the wood planer.

In 2011, Dolorita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dolorita is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase tools needed for maintenance of the equipment. This will be the first loan taken out by Dolorita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Abdullo

texts.ru: Ибодов Абдулло проживает в районе Восеъ. Возраст, 38 лет. Женат. Имеет 4 детей. Жена домохозяйка. Он живет вместе с родителями. Его отец работает в средней школе. Сам он более семи лет занимается растениеводством. В основном он сеет пшеницу и лук для продажи. Кредит берет для закупа семян и минеральных удобрений.

His father works in the secondary school. Abdullo has been in agriculture for more than seven years. He mainly sows wheat and onion for resale. He is taking out the loan to buy seeds and mineral fertilizer.

loans.name: Tungalag

texts.en:

Her two older children attend college, while the younger one goes to a local secondary school. With the help of her husband, Tungalag manages a shoe-making business that she started in 1998 after working at a shoe-making factory for eight years.

A diligent woman who is thankful to our bank for giving her a start-up loan to begin her business, she is planning to expand in the future. Tungalag is now requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more materials for her shoe-making business.

loans.use: to purchase shoe-making materials for her business

loans.name: Shareefan's Group

texts.en:
Shareefan has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the expansion of her husband’s business selling animals. Using the loan, he will purchase goats and sheep for resale to earn good profit. His business grows busier during the Muslim festival of Eid-ul-Azha because people purchase animals to slaughter. At other times he sells animals to butchers. 

Shareefan is confident that her husband’s eight years of experience in his business will help him getting better profits as a result of an investment.  She resides in a small city called Khanewal located in Punjab province of Pakistan. She has been living there in the area of Shanti Nagar with her family in a 2-room brick house for the past 10 years. 
  
She herself is a housewife, prefering to stay at home and do her household responsibilities. She is the mother of three sons. Only one of them is enrolled in a local school and getting his education.   

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Shareefan.

loans.name: Batbaatar

texts.en:
Batbaatar is 34 years old and lives with his wife and two children, ages 7 and 15, in a ger, a Mongolian traditional nomadic housing tent, in Zavhan province of Mongolia. His two children both attend local secondary school while his wife helps with the family shoe-making business. 

Batbaatar started his business in 2004 at his home. Batbaatar is responsible for making the traditional handicraft footwear items, including shoes, boots, sandals etc.. On the other hand his wife, Bayasgalan, is responsible for selling their shoes at a rented stall at a trading center. They have managed to build a strong customer base and their customers are satisfied with the quality and uniqueness. Batbaatar and his wife are planning to expand and continue their business in the future. 

He is a hardworking man who says, "I want to buy a sophisticated sewing machine in order to increase our product sales." He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase a sewing machine from China and some materials for his business.

loans.use: to purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:

Having repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. she is now requesting a new loan of 30000 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be Rosita's eighth loan from ASKI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:

Her house is located in Shanti Nagar which is a small residential area where she has been living with her family in a 3-room brick house for the past 25 years. She is a housewife, staying at home and doing her household responsibilities. She is a very caring person and tries to give comfort to her family by fulfilling their needs. 

Her husband's name is S. M. and he operates a vegetable-selling business. His shop is located in the market and he offers fresh seasonal vegetables to his customers at reasonable rates. He has been operating this business for the past 10 years. 

Nasreen has given birth to one son who is 15 years old and works in a private company and financially contributes to the family. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business to use in buying fresh seasonal vegetables for his shop. Nasreen is confident that an investment will help him making more money from his business. 

She is a new loan user and this is her first loan application to Asasah. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Nasreen.

loans.name: Bolorchimeg

texts.en:
Bolorchimeg, 39, is married and lives with her husband and two sons in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in the Zavhan province of Mongolia. Her oldest son goes to a local secondary school while the youngest attends kindergarten. 

Her husband used to herd husbandry animals bet became a taxi driver in 2010. She operates a shoe-making business in her town. She started her business in 1995 at her home. She makes variety of shoes using leather, rubber, plastic and other materials. Her shoes are well-known for their durability amongst her customers. 

Before her shoe making business she used to conduct a traditional clothing making business for 5 years. Therefore she is quite experienced in managing and operating her business. She is a diligent woman who says, "I want to receive the loan in order to expand my business. I definitely will pay back the loan on time." She is requesting a 1,800,000 Mongolian tugrug (MNT) loan to purchase leather, rubber and some glue for her shoe-making business.

loans.name: Darisuren

texts.en:
Darisuren is 40-year-old widow who lives with her three children in her brother's backyard in Uvs province, Mongolia. They live in a 'ger', a Mongolian traditional nomadic housing tent. Her older two children are students and the youngest one is a pupil. She manages a grocery trading business in her town. 

She started her business in June 2010 out of a rented container at a local market. At first her working capital was 1,500,000 MNT which has increased to 2,000,000 MNT. Her business is quite profitable and allows her to pay the education costs of her children. She is planning to continue and expand her business in the future. She is a polite woman who says, "I would like to have my own plot of land where I can build my own house." She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more grocery items for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items.

loans.name: Narzullo

texts.en:
S. Narzullo is an active 47-year-old father. His wife is a housewife. He is a farmer and also, he is engaged in animal husbandry. The income he earns from this business allows him to take care of his family of two children and his wife. 

Narzullo would like to increase his harvest in order to maximize his income, and to do so he needs to buy fertilizer, seeds. In addition to this he would like to buy cattle and pay salaries for his workers. As he lacks the financial means to do all this, Narzullo is requesting a loan of 9000 Somoni to help him buy cattle, fertilizer and seeds.
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy cattle, fertilizer and seeds.

Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. For over ten years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to her local neighbours and passersby. Mwanasha faces a major challenge of inflation in the market of her products.

With the Kshs 40,000 she is requesting, she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and sacks of sugar.  She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

Sarapio is a fifty-four-year-old married man with four children living in a semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is charged with the responsibility of looking after his wife and children with no other dependents. His dream is to build a permanent house and have an educated family.

Sarapio brews alcohol for a living and has also been a carpenter for over twenty years. He has challenges of limited capital to meet the increasing demand of his customers and his aspiration is to diversify and trade in cattle. Sarapio intends to use the loan to brew alcohol.

loans.use: To brew alcohol.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase building materials for her food stall (timber, iron sheets) and pay labor.

loans.name: Dina

texts.en:
Dina M. is from the village of Tayong, Sagay, Camiguin Province. She is 44 years old. Dina is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Dina owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, snack foods, shampoo, soap & beverages in the local community. Dina has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Dina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dina is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional snack foods & detergents. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Dina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional snack foods & detergents.

loans.name: Sakina's Group

texts.en:
Sakina is a caring lady who spends her time at home and carries out her responsibilities as a housewife. She belongs to a small city in Punjab, Pakistan called Chichawatni which is famous for its agriculture industry. She has been living there in the area of A. Nagar in a 2-room brick house for many years.  

She is the mother of three children. All of them are getting education from a local school. Her brother also lives with her and he is involved in a plastic crockery sets sales business. He operates his business in the market and financially contributes Sakina and her family. 

Sakina has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her brother who wants to buy crockery to sell to his customers and earn better profits. Sakina is hopeful that her brother who has been operating this business for the past four years will successfully be able to further grow his business after the loan investment and increase his profits. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Sakina.

loans.use: To buy plastic crockery for resale.

loans.name: Djélika

texts.fr:
Madame Djélika Sangaré est âgée de 49 ans, mariée et mère de 3 enfants, elle réside avec son mari et ses enfants dans une famille monogame au quartier  Koko de la ville de Koutiala (Région de Sikasso). 
Elle a fréquenté l’école mais n’a pas pu l’achever pour des raisons familiales. C’est ainsi qu’elle décida d’embrasser les activités génératrices de revenus, apprises auprès de sa maman depuis maintenant plus d’une décennie. Après avoir mené plusieurs activités, elle finit par opter pour l’achat vente du bois de chauffe il y a 7 ans.  
Le bois de chauffe est un des éléments essentiel pour les femmes Maliennes  dans la  préparation des repas (faire la cuisine),  raisons pour laquelle, Madame Djélika peut vendre 3 chargements de camion remorque par mois.  
A L’approche de l’hivernage, moment de ruptures du bois de chauffe, Djélika, dans son souci de prévenir ce manque, décide de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso, avec qui, elle est à son premier prêt.   
Madame Djélika  envisage utiliser ce prêt pour acheter  des chargements de bois de chauffe auprès des paysans des villages  environnants  de Koutiala  et elle effectue sa vente  devant sa porte au quartier Koko, à une clientèle mixte, au comptant et en détail.  
Elle espère réaliser un  bénéfice de 125 000FCFA par mois qu’elle utilisera pour le remboursement du prêt de Soro Yiriwaso, contribuer aux dépenses quotidiennes  de sa famille et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs. Djelika Sangare is 49 years old and married with three children. She lives with her husband and children in a monogamous family, and resides in the Koko neighborhood in the city of Koutiala (Sikasso region).
She went to school but could not complete her education for family reasons. This is how she decided to undertake revenues-generating activities, learnt at her mother's side for over a decade now. After trying several occupations, she finally chose the firewood trade seven years ago.
Firewood is one of the essential elements for Malian women to prepare meals (cooking), which account for Mrs. Djelika being able to sell three trailer truckloads a month.
With wintering drawing near, a time where firewood is often oversold, Djelika decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution and take her first loan, in order to avert the shortage.
Mrs. Djelika envisions using this loan to purchase bundles of firewood from farmers in the villages surrounding Koutiala. She retails in front of her door in the Koko neighborhood, to a varied clientele.
She hopes to make a monthly benefit of FCFA 125,000; she will use it to pay back the Soro Yiriwaso loan, participate to the daily expenses of the family, and will invest the remainder in her business.

loans.use: to purchase firewood

loans.name: Richie

texts.en:
Richie B. is from the village of Poblacion, Sagay, Camiguin Province. He is 28 years old. Richie is single. To make a living, Richie owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling spices like onions & garlic, noodles, pepper & laurel leaf in the local community. Richie has been engaged in his business for over one year and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Richie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Richie is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional spices & noodles. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Richie from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional spices & noodles.

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is a twenty-nine-year-old married man with two children living in his own permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is a driver by trade and has been in service for five years. In order to increase his income he started a poultry project from his salary savings and the business is growing despite challenges of high cost of feeds. His dream is to buy a taxi and also expand his project. James needs the loan to buy chicks.

loans.use: To buy chicks for poultry farming.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy clothes at wholesale to add to his business

loans.name: Rehana's Group

texts.en:
Rehana has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the growth of her brother’s meat selling business. Using the loan, he will buy goats and chickens to fulfill the demand of his clients and increase his income. He has been offering his services for many years and his customers are satisfied with his quality meat that is good in weight. 

Rehana is a widow. After the death of her husband she moved to her brother’s home with her four children. Due to poor financial conditions, she is only able to provide education to her elder daughter. 

She belongs to Chichawatni which is a small city located in Punjab, Pakistan, known for its agriculture industry. She is hopeful that after investing the loan money into her brother’s business, her brother will be able to expand his business further and increase his profits.

loans.use: To buy goats and chickens for her brother's butcher shop.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 21-year-old single man from Lebanon living with his parents and two siblings. He has been working in his own vegetable shop for the past four years. He sells all types of vegetables such as tomatoes, cucumbers, and lettuce, etc. 

This young man knows how to benefit from life opportunities since at the same time, he has been working as a pet dealer for two years in order to make extra money for the family. We note that he is a hard worker running double jobs and pursuing his education at the same time.  

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase supplementary goods to increase his sales and thus his income. In the future, he is planning to make his shop bigger by adding more merchandise to it such as fruits, daily necessities, and dairy products .

loans.use: to purchase supplementary products.

loans.name: Loreta

texts.en:
Loreta D. is from the village of Poblacion, Sagay, Camiguin Province. She is 40 years old and married with four adult children. To make a living, Loreta owns & operates a business buying and selling pillow cases, bed sheets and blankets.She has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2011, Loreta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional stock of blankets & pillow cases. This will be the first loan taken out by Loreta from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock of blankets & pillow cases

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy L. is from the village of Mayana, Sagay, Camiguin Province. She is 30 years old. Mercy is separated from her spouse and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Mercy sells fish like sardines, milk fish and mackerel in the local community. Mercy has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month. 

In 2011, Mercy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell like mackerel & sardines. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Mercy from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue  to improve her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish like mackerel & sardines to sell

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is a thirty-five-year-old married woman with four children living in her own semi permanent house in Fort Portal Uganda. She takes care of the family with the help of her husband who is a herbalist and their goal is to work hard and build a permanent house to live in. Agnes sells clothes and has been in business for three year. Her initial capital was 300,000 shillings but she currently has working capital of 2,000,000 shillings and the business is still growing despite challenges in high tax and transport costs. Agnes wants the money to buy clothes as the easter season is fast approaching.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Penina

texts.en:
Penina N. M. is 36 years old, married to Joseph with no children. She has been running a greengrocer shop where she sells assorted types of vegetables to her customers and passersby.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by a credit officer, and is applying for her third loan of KES.20,000 from KADET to increase her stock of cabbages, potatoes, tomatoes, and bananas.

With the anticipated profit, she will open another income-generating project. Penina hopes to be successful in business. She is very hardworking lady.

loans.use: to buy vegetables like cabbages, potatoes, tomatoes and bananas

loans.name: Asghari's Group

texts.en:
Asghari belongs to Chichawatni which is a small city located in Punjab, Pakistan, known for its agriculture industry. She lives there in a single room brick house with her family in the area of Ahmed Nagar. She moved here a few years ago. She is married to Q. J. who operates a fruit-selling business. His shop is located in the market and he offers his clients fresh seasonal fruit at cheap rates. 

Asghari married recently and has no child yet. She is a caring lady who manages her household responsibilities very well. Besides her household work, she operates her clothes-selling business to financially contribute her family.  She purchases the clothing from wholesale markets of Chichawatni and sells to her local area clients at a profit. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her husband’s business. Using the loan, he will purchase fresh seasonal fruit to sell in his shop.  He has been operating his business for the past five years and Asghari is confident that he will be able to earn good profit from his business after making an investment in it. 

She is a new loan user and this is her first loan application to Asasah. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Asghari.

loans.use: To buy fresh seasonal fruit for fruit-selling business.

loans.name: Zena

texts.en: Zena M. is married and has four children, all of whom attend school. They own a house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. Zena operates a food vending business, selling as wholesale and from home to her neighbors. The business has enabled her educate her children and improve their standard of living. Zena faces the challenges of the high cost of transportation and seasonality in her business. She dreams of owning a café in the future. Zena is requesting a loan for 20,000 KES, which she will use to purchase timber and iron sheets to build a food vending stall. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to raise her business standards.

loans.use: To purchase timber and iron sheets to build a food vending stall

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna B. is from the village of Abu, Baylao, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 45 years old, married, and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Myrna owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling coconuts in the local community. Myrna has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month.

In 2011, Myrna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myrna is requesting a loan of ,5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional coconuts to sell. This loan will be Myrna's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase coconuts to sell

loans.name: Ailene

texts.en:
Ailene S. is from the village of Cabuan, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 42 years old, married, and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Ailene owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling canned goods, snack foods, shampoo, soap, and beverages in the local community. Ailene has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Ailene joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ailene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase additional inventory and acquire working capital. Ailene is requesting a new loan for 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, beverages, and snack foods. This loan will be Ailene's fourth loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional canned goods, beverages, and snack foods

loans.name: Christine

texts.en: Christine is 32 years old, married, and has four children. They live in a rented house in Fort Portal, Uganda.She and the husband complement each other in taking care of the home. Their dream is to buy land and build a house. Christine has a clothing shop where her challenge comes from price fluctuation. Christine is requesting a loan to buy clothes to sell.

loans.use: To purchase clothes to sell

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima is a widow with six children, all of whom graduated from school. She owns a house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family.
For the past ten years, Halima has operated a business selling maandazi (dumplings) from door to door and from home to her neighbors. The main challenge she faces in her business is seasonality. She dreams of establishing real estate houses in the future. With her 20,000 KES loan, she wants to renovate her house and purchase blocks and cement. Halima decided to join Kiva partner, Yehu, to access loans to raise her living standards.

loans.use: to renovate her house and purchase blocks and cement

loans.name: Analie

texts.en:
Analie S. is from the village of Liong, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 35 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Analie owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling canned goods, snack foods, beverages, shampoo, soap and biscuits in the local community. Analie has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2011, Analie joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Analie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods and snack foods. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase canned goods and snack foods

loans.name: Deus

texts.en: Deus is a 23-year-old married man with a child. He lives in Fort Portal, Uganda. The responsibility to look after the family rests solely on him and his desire is to set up a stable income-generating activity for the family. Deus operates a shop and has been in business for two years. His business is steadily growing despite challenges and limited funds. Deus needs the loan facility to buy sugar, maize flour and soap for resale.

loans.use: to buy sugar, maize flour and soap for resale

loans.name: Selfa

texts.en:
Selfa is a married woman with three school-going children. They live in a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are rent bills and food for the family.
For the past five years, Selfa has operated a fresh water sales business, selling wholesale, at the market and from door to door. The major business challenge she faces is the high cost of transportation and seasonality in her business. She dreams of owning a matatu (public motor vehicle) in the future. With her loan of 20,000 KES she wants to pay school fees for her child. She decided to work with Kiva partner, Yehu, to access loans to raise her standard of living.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her child

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary N. is 60 years old. She lives in the Kakheti Region, in the village of Khashmi, with her daughter, son-in-law and two little grandchildren. Mary works as an office cleaner in a local company and earns 150 Laris per month. Mary’s daughter trades golden jewelry. Her average monthly profit is 300 Laris. Mary’s son-in-law works in a local institution in the position of logistic/provider. Besides the above-mentioned jobs, family members are engaged in agricultural activities: they have three milk cows and make cheese, which is sold in Tbilisi (the capital city of the country). 

With the requested amount, they will buy two additional milk cows and will be able to produce and sell more cheese and increase their income. 

The increase in the income will be reinvested in their farming business. Mary hopes she will be able to expand her farm, increase the income of the family and respectively improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to buy milk cows

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is a married woman with two children – one attends school while the other is too young for school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is rent bills.
For the past two years, Alice has operated a business selling cooking gas cylinders, both retail and at the market. Alice faces the major challenge of high transport costs and seasonality in her business. In the future, she dreams of establishing a wholesale shop selling cooking gas. With her 30,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase 20 gas cylinders. Alice decided to join Kiva partner, Yehu, to access loans to raise her business standards.

loans.use: to purchase 20 gas cylinders

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen K. M.  is 24 years old, married to Faith Mutindi and does not have children. He has been running a retail shop in Tala town, making an income of 10,000 KES. He learned about Kiva partner, KADET, through group members registered with KADET, and he is applying for his first loan, which he will use to purchase more stock for the shop such as cooking oil, flour, sugar, tea leaves and sweets for resale. Stephen intends to use the anticipated profits to save and plow back into his business. In the future, he plans to grow his business and become stable financially.

loans.use: to purchase more stock such as cooking oil, flour, sugar, tea leaves and sweets

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 49-year-old married woman from Lebanon. She is living with her husband and two school-age children. She has been working as a freelance hairdresser since 1993. She cooperates with her husband, who works in a local company, pay the living expenses and most important pay for the children's education.  In two years, her husband will retire and she will be the only working member in the family. That’s why she aims to guarantee the future of her business so that she will be able to support the family at the upcoming period. 

Today, she is requesting to borrow $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase hairdressing tools and beauty products. She is very optimistic and planning to open her own beauty salon as soon as she can to welcome the customers properly.

loans.use: to purchase hairdressing tools and beauty products.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase sacks of beans, wheat flour and potatoes

loans.name: Mwanamwaka

texts.en:
Mwanamwaka is a single woman with four children; three still attend school while one graduated from school. They own a house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.
Mwanamwaka has operated a food vending business for the past seven years, cooking chapati (flat bread), beans and rice for sale. Mwanamwaka has been selling her food from door to door and from home to her neighbors. She dreams of establishing a café in the future.
With her loan of 30,000 KES, Mwanamwaka wants to purchase blocks to build her food stall, a bundle of wheat flour and potatoes. She decided to join Kiva partner, Yehu, to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase blocks to build her food stall, a bundle of wheat flour and potatoes

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy gara lapper making materials – ink, caustic soda, powder, white cotton cloths, etc. in order to produce a larger quantity of cloths for sale

loans.name: La Gloire Du Seigneur Group

texts.fr: N. B.  est entrepreneur, présidente du groupe d’affaire « La Gloire du Seigneur »,  âgée de 48 ans, mariée, mère de 8 enfants et tous fréquentent l’école. Son mari est une sentinelle dans une entreprise Pétrolière « Station Africom ». La cliente N. B. est vendeuse des produits des denrées alimentaires. Elle s’installe au long de la rue donnant axer aux avenues de son quartier. Elle vient de réaliser 8 cycles opérationnels en bénéficiant de crédit de l’IMF  Hekima. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner avec des nouveaux produits (30 kilos d’arachides, 1 bidon d’huile, 50 kilos de haricots, 25 kilos de riz, etc. En plus, elle ambitionne agrandir son entreprise et construire confortablement une maison pour sa famille.  La cliente N. B. remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique. Il sied de signaler que le groupe d’affaire «  La Gloire du Seigneur » est majoritairement féminins.
texts.en: N. B. is an entrepreneur, president of the business group "The Glory of the Lord". She is 48 years old, married, and the mother of 8 children, all of whom are in school. Her husband is a watchman in "Station Africom," a petroleum company. N. B. sells food products. She set herself up along the street that runs through the avenues of her neighborhood. She has just completed 8 operational cycles while benefiting from MFI Hekima loans. This new loan will enable her to stock up with new products (30 kilos of peanuts, a can of oil, 50 kilos of beans, 25 kilos of rice, etc..) In addition, her goal is to expand her company and to build a comfortable home for her family. N. B. thanks Hekima for its actions in favor of poor people excluded from traditional banks. It should be noted that the business group "The Glory of the Lord" is mostly women.

loans.use: To buy 30 kilos of peanuts, 1can of oil, 50 kilos of beans, 25 kilos of rice, etc.
